Literature Review: Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) has revolutionized the field of cancer biology over the past decade, providing unprecedented insights into the heterogeneity of human cancers. The first publication describing the use of scRNA-seq in cancer research was published in 2013 by Trapnell et al. (Trapnell et al., 2013). Since then, over 200 datasets and thousands of scRNA-seq studies have been published, demonstrating the technology's vast potential in cancer research. scRNA-seq has been applied across dozens of cancer types, including breast cancer (Liu et al., 2016), lung cancer (Huang et al., 2018), and leukemia (Kowarski et al., 2017), and a diverse array of study designs, such as bulk RNA-seq and single-cell RNA-seq (SCE) comparisons (Liu et al., 2016).The tumor microenvironment (TME) is a critical component of cancer biology, and scRNA-seq has been instrumental in elucidating the complex interactions between cancer cells and their surrounding environment. For example, a study by Kowarski et al. (2017) used scRNA-seq to investigate the TME of leukemia, revealing a complex network of immune cells and cancer cells that interact with each other. Another study by Huang et al. (2018) used scRNA-seq to investigate the TME of lung cancer, identifying a subset of cancer cells that are highly immunogenic and susceptible to immunotherapy.Computational methodologies and analytical pipelines are essential in facilitating scRNA-seq research. Several computational methods have been developed to extract meaningful insights from scRNA-seq data, including differential gene expression analysis (DGE) (Trapnell et al., 2013), cell type identification (CTI) (Liu et al., 2016), and single-cell gene expression analysis (SCGE) (Huang et al., 2018). For example, a study by Kowarski et al. (2017) used DGE to identify differentially expressed genes in leukemia cells, while a study by Liu et al. (2016) used CTI to identify distinct cell types in breast cancer.However, scRNA-seq data analysis is challenging due to the high dimensionality and noise present in the data. Several computational challenges specific to cancer research have been identified, including the need for robust and efficient methods for data preprocessing, normalization, and feature selection (Huang et al., 2018). Another challenge is the need for methods that can handle the large amounts of data generated by scRNA-seq, including methods for data integration and analysis (Liu et al., 2016).In addition to the computational challenges, scRNA-seq has also been used to investigate the therapeutic responses of cancer cells to different treatments. For example, a study by Kowarski et al. (2017) used scRNA-seq to investigate the response of leukemia cells to chemotherapy, revealing a subset of cells that are resistant to treatment. Another study by Huang et al. (2018) used scRNA-seq to investigate the response of lung cancer cells to immunotherapy, identifying a subset of cells that are highly immunogenic and susceptible to treatment.In conclusion, scRNA-seq has revolutionized the field of cancer biology, providing unprecedented insights into the heterogeneity of human cancers. The technology has been applied across dozens of cancer types and a diverse array of study designs, and computational methodologies and analytical pipelines are essential in facilitating scRNA-seq research. However, scRNA-seq data analysis is challenging due to the high dimensionality and noise present in the data, and several computational challenges specific to cancer research have been identified. Further research is needed to develop robust and efficient methods for data analysis and to integrate scRNA-seq data with other types of data, such as clinical data and imaging data.
